review.title: Exploring the Combination Rules of D Numbers From a Perspective of Conflict Redistribution
review.abstract: Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence is widely applied to uncertainty modelling and knowledge reasoning because of its advantages in dealing with uncertain information. But some conditions or requirements, such as exclusiveness hypothesis and completeness constraint, limit the development and application of that theory to a large extend. To overcome the shortcomings and enhance its capability of representing the uncertainty, a novel model, called D numbers, has been proposed recently. However, many key issues, for example how to implement the combination of D numbers, remain unsolved. In the paper, we have explored the combination of D Numbers from a perspective of conflict redistribution, and proposed two combination rules being suitable for different situations for the fusion of two D numbers. The proposed combination rules can reduce to the classical Dempster's rule in Dempster-Shafer theory under a certain conditions. Numerical examples and discussion about the proposed rules are also given in the paper.

sections.heading: III. D NUMBERS
sections.text: There are several strong hypotheses and limitations regarding FOD and BPA. However, these hypotheses and limitations limit the ability of DST to represent uncertain information. (1) In many situations, however, it is very difficult to be satisfied. (2) In the assessment of an object, linguistic variables are often used to express the assessment result, such as "Very Good," "Fair," "Very Bad" and "Very Bad." Inevitably, there is an overlap between these linguistic variables. Therefore, exclusivity can be guaranteed in such a way that the application of DST to such situations is fragmented. (2) There are already some studies on FOD with non-exclusive hypotheses. (2)

sections.heading: IV. PROPOSED COMBINATION RULES FOR D NUMBERS
sections.text: In daylight saving time, Dempster's combination rule is mainly used to synthesize all the knowledge involved in the original BPAs. However, the combination of D numbers is still an unsolved problem in current research. In this paper, a combination rule for D numbers is proposed to synthesize uncertain information from the perspective of conflict redistribution as used in daylight saving time. Before introducing the combination rule, we will first examine the non-exclusivity of D numbers.

sections.heading: A. Non-exclusiveness in D numbers
sections.text: Non-exclusivity is the opposite of exclusivity. Exclusivity refers to the property that one object excludes the others. For example, we assume that there are two suggestions A and B, we say that they are mutually exclusive when A, B and B are mutually exclusive. (This means that the concept of non-exclusivity is an either / or related thing, but not the similarity.) As mentioned above, the elements in FOD are not required to be mutually exclusive, which means that Fi is not completely exclusive to Fj, Fj and also Bi is not completely exclusive to Bj, even Bi and Bj Bj Bj = not completely exclusive to Bi, for non-empty sets Bi, Bj and Bj are not exclusive.

sections.heading: V. DISCUSSION
sections.text: In this paper, we have given two combination rules for D numbers, namely DCR1 and DCR2. In fact, DCR1 is fully contained in DCR2. Therefore, it is only necessary to analyze and discuss the combination rule DCR2. Overall, the main advantage of the proposed combination rule DCR2 is that it simultaneously takes into account the non-exclusivity and incompleteness of information that are the two main features of the D numbers by integrating the idea of global conflict redistribution and partial conflict redistribution from daylight saving time. Essentially, DCR2 can be seen as a generalization of the Dempster rule for the model of D numbers, as it can be completely reduced to the classical Dempster rule under certain conditions. The paper provides a practical combination rule for D numbers. Based on this rule, the theory of D numbers can really be applied in many related fields of application. Meanwhile, we must admit that there are some disadvantages within the proposed rule.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Inspired by related research in daylight saving time, two new combination rules, DCR1 and DCR2, have been proposed for the combination of two D numbers based on the perspective of conflict redistribution. DCR1 is suitable for the situation of non-exclusivity and information completeness, and DCR2 can be used in the case of non-exclusivity and information incompleteness. DCR2 has generalized DCR1. Both of these rules can degenerate into the classical Dempster rule in daylight saving time. In this sense, the model of D numbers with the proposed combination rules is compatible with the framework of daylight saving time. Finally, the characteristics of these rules have been discussed. Future research will examine the combination of several D numbers (≥ 3), and also the properties and applications of the combination rules for D numbers will be further investigated.

INTRODUCTION Since first proposed by Dempster and developed by Shafer, Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence [1], [2], also called Dempster-Shafer theory (DST) or belief function theory, has been paid much attention for a long time and continually attracted growing interests [3], [4].

INTRODUCTION Since first proposed by Dempster and developed by Shafer, Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence [1], [2], also called Dempster-Shafer theory (DST) or belief function theory, has been paid much attention for a long time and continually attracted growing interests [3], [4].

INTRODUCTION Since first proposed by Dempster and developed by Shafer, Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence [1], [2], also called Dempster-Shafer theory (DST) or belief function theory, has been paid much attention for a long time and continually attracted growing interests [3], [4].
This theory needs weaker conditions than the Bayesian theory of probability, so it is often regarded as an extension of the Bayesian theory [5].

Due to its advantages in handling uncertain information, DST has been extensively used in many fields, such as information fusion, statistical learning, classification and clustering, granular computing, uncertainty and knowledge reasoning, decision making, risk assessment and evaluation, knowledgebased systems and expert systems, and so forth [6], [7], [8], [9], [10].

To overcome the shortcomings and enhance its capability of representing the uncertainty, a novel model, called D numbers, has been proposed recently. However, many key issues, for example how to implement the combination of D numbers, remain unsolved. The proposed combination rules can reduce to the classical Dempster’s rule in Dempster-Shafer theory under a certain conditions. Numerical examples and discussion about the proposed rules are also given in the paper.
